Demand side management is perceived as a tool to support a secure and reliable energy system operation amid growing integration of renewable energy resources. However, the lack of scalable modeling and control procedures hinders the practical implementation. To address this challenge, this paper proposes a novel signal matrix model predictive control algorithm. Compared to existing data-driven methods, this approach explicitly provides stochastic predictions considering both disturbance and measurement errors with few tuning parameters, ensuring reliability by high-probability constraint satisfaction. The performance is extensively compared with three state-of-the-art algorithms in a space heating case study using a high-fidelity simulator. The results are further validated with physical experiments using the same system that the simulator is based on. To assess transferability, the algorithm is further implemented on diverse controlled systems, including a domestic hot water heating system and a stationary electric battery. The simulation results show that, compared to existing data-driven methods, the proposed approach improves constraint satisfaction and energy savings by up to 90 % and 8 %, respectively. The experimental results further confirm that the algorithm is applicable to multiple tasks of demand side management, with reasonable control performance observed in all case studies. Keywords Data-driven control Building energy management Signal matrix model predictive control Demand side management Space heating Domestic hot water heating Data availability Data will be made available on request. Nomenclature DeePC Data-Enabled Predictive Control DHW Domestic Hot Water DSM Demand Side Management MPC Model Predictive Control OCP Optimal Control Problem OPC Open Platform Communications PLC Programmable Logic Controller SH Space Heating SMM-PC Signal Matrix Model Predictive Control SOC State of Charge SPC Subspace Predictive Control 1 Introduction While the increasing penetration of renewable energy resources contributes to mitigating climate change, the intermittency in their production is expected to significantly challenge the energy system operation. Meanwhile, the International Energy Agency estimates that one billion households and eleven billion smart appliances could actively participate in demand response programs globally by 2040 [1, p. 83], which can be seen as a subcategory of demand side management (DSM). This opens up the possibility of applying active DSM on a large scale to cope with the surge of renewable energy, as well as facilitating energy conservation and improving the occupants’ comfort. In the existing literature, model predictive control (MPC) [2] has been viewed as a promising control strategy to enable DSM [3]. For example, MPC is used to provide distributed coordination of buildings to support flexible energy infrastructure operation, as shown in Refs. [4,5]. However, due to the large number of heterogeneous controlled systems, first-principles modeling approaches cannot ensure timely and cost-effective implementation. In fact, modeling often takes up the majority of the budget in applying model-based control, in terms of both time and cost [6,7]. Therefore, data-driven control methods have recently received considerable attention [8]. This work addresses this challenge by developing a novel data-driven control algorithm and systematically assessing its performance across heterogeneous components in simulation and experimental studies. 1.1 Critical literature review Experimentally validated data-driven controllers in the literature can be broadly classified into three categories: model-free approaches based on reinforcement learning [9], machine-learning-based modeling of physical systems [10], and data-driven predictive control based on the behavioral system theory [11,12]. A qualitative comparison between these methods is reported in [13]. Additionally, Kazmi et al. [9] report poor generalization capability of reinforcement learning for the same type of loads in a large-scale experimental study. Bünning et al. [14] conclude with a comprehensive comparison that machine-learning-based modeling performs worse than the classical approach based on linear regression and has poor sample efficiency. Despite many machine learning techniques being known to be susceptible to small perturbations [15], both works do not consider measurement noise explicitly, which is unrealistic in the residential building sector. Additionally, most studies only focus on one type of controlled system without evaluating the controller’s transferability, which is insufficient given our task of controlling different types of heterogeneous systems on the demand side. This work focuses on data-driven predictive control methods based on the behavioral system theory [16]. Compared with techniques based on machine learning, such methods are known to have excellent data efficiency with minimum training and tuning effort but are not inherently adapted to nonlinearities [13]. The methods along this line include MPC based on subspace identification [17–19], indirect methods such as subspace predictive control (SPC) [20], and direct methods such as data-enabled predictive control (DeePC) [21]. However, the subspace-identification-based approach requires additional model order selection and state observer design procedures. While DeePC provides a simple implementation pipeline, tuning the hyperparameters can be extremely time-intensive. DeePC is also not easily interpretable since the input–output mapping is not well-defined. More specifically, the characteristics and mathematical details of these methods are reviewed and distinguished in Section 2.2. More importantly, reliable frameworks to obtain uncertainty models for robust constraint satisfaction are not available yet, which is crucial for building-related applications. In this work, a novel indirect data-driven predictive control framework, dubbed signal matrix model predictive control (SMM-PC), is presented. SMM-PC is first proposed in [22,23] with maximum likelihood prediction. Reliable stochastic prediction under noise is later provided in [24], which is very difficult to obtain in other data-driven methods. On the other hand, stochastic MPC approaches have been widely studied in the literature [25] and applied in the building sector [26], and guarantee high-probability constraint satisfaction by enforcing chance constraints. Similar techniques can be applied to stochastic data-driven predictors. 1.2 Unique contribution and paper organization The contributions of this work are threefold. Firstly, the existing SMM-PC algorithm is extended to explicitly account for disturbances and measurement noise by incorporating the stochastic control framework with chance constraints. This algorithm provides a disciplined yet easy-to-implement approach to achieve reliable operation with data-driven methods under various uncertainties. Secondly, the performance is extensively analyzed by comparing multiple state-of-the-art data-driven algorithms using a high-fidelity simulator for space heating (SH) control. Results demonstrate that the proposed stochastic SMM-PC algorithm not only satisfies operating constraints more reliably than competing methods, but it also reduces energy consumption at the same time. In addition, experiments have been carried out to validate the controller’s performance on the same facility on which the simulator has been built. Lastly, the transferability is experimentally evaluated across different types of controlled systems, including a domestic hot water (DHW) heating system and a stationary electric battery. It is demonstrated that the SMM-PC algorithm is easily transferable to different types of controlled systems with satisfactory performance since there are very few tuning parameters involved. The rest of this paper is structured as follows. The next section briefly revisits the theoretical background of data-driven predictive control and introduces the stochastic SMM-PC algorithm. Section 3 describes simulation and experimental case studies to evaluate the performance and transferability of the proposed algorithm. Multiple algorithms are then benchmarked using a high-fidelity simulator, and the results are summarized in Section 4. Experimental validation and transferability results are summarized in Section 5. Finally, Section 6 concludes the work and outlines future work. 2 Methodology In this section, the theoretical background of data-driven predictive control is briefly revisited, and various extensions to account for noise and uncertainties are discussed. The prediction accuracy using the indirect approach with the signal matrix model is then quantified. Finally, a stochastic indirect data-driven predictive control scheme with constraint tightening is presented to ensure that constraints are satisfied with a predefined probability. Notation. The expected value and covariance of a random variable are denoted by E [ ⋅ ] and cov ( ⋅ ) , respectively. The symbol P ( ⋅ ) indicates the probability of a random event. For a sequence of matrices X 1 , … , X n , we denote [ X 1 ⊤ … X n ⊤ ] ⊤ by col X 1 , … , X n . Given a signal x : Z → R n , its trajectory from k to k + N − 1 is indicated by ( x i ) i = k k + N − 1 = col ( x k , … , x k + N − 1 ) . For a vector x , ‖ x ‖ P denotes the weighted l 2 -norm ( x ⊤ P x ) 1 2 . The rank and trace of a matrix are indicated by rank ( ⋅ ) and tr ( ⋅ ) , respectively. 2.1 Data-driven predictive control Consider a discrete-time linear time-invariant (LTI) dynamical system with disturbance and output noise, given by (1) x t + 1 = A x t + B u t + E w t , y t = C x t + D u t + v t , where x t ∈ R n x , u t ∈ R n u , y t ∈ R n y , w t ∈ R n w , and v t ∈ R n y are the states, inputs, outputs, disturbance, and output noise, respectively. The noise v t is considered to be zero-mean, independent, and identically distributed with a variance of σ 2 . The noise-free output is denoted by y t 0 . In conventional MPC algorithms, the output is predicted and controlled by iteratively propagating the state-space model (1), assuming the knowledge of the model parameters ( A , B , C , D , E ) is available. In data-driven predictive control, however, no prior knowledge about the parameters is required, but a matrix of input-disturbance-output trajectory data (2) Z = z 0 d ⋯ z M − 1 d has to be collected from historical data or high-fidelity simulation, where each column (3) z i d = col u t i d , … , u t i + L − 1 d , w t i d , … , w t i + L − 1 d , y t i d , … , y t i + L − 1 d is a length- L trajectory of the system. This matrix is referred to as the signal matrix [22]. Using Willems’ fundamental lemma [27] in the behavioral system theory, a nonparametric input–output mapping can be directly obtained from the signal matrix Z when no noise is present, i.e., v t = 0 [28]. The method is summarized as follows. With sufficiently persistently exciting inputs, the range space of Z contains all possible trajectories of the system. Let L = L 0 + L ′ , and L 0 be no smaller than the observability index of the system. Define a partition of Z as (4) Z = col U , W , Y p , Y f = col Ψ , Y p , Y f , where U ∈ R n u L × M , W ∈ R n w L × M , Y p ∈ R n y L 0 × M , Y f ∈ R n y L ′ × M , and Ψ ∈ R ( n u + n w ) L × M . The noise-free signal matrix satisfies the rank condition (5) rank ( Z ) = rank col Ψ , Y p = ( n u + n w ) L + n x . Then, the L ′ -step-ahead output predictor y t = ( y k ) k = t t + L ′ − 1 at time t can be constructed from the past input sequence u ini t = ( u k ) k = t − L 0 t − 1 , the future input sequence u t = ( u k ) k = t t + L ′ − 1 , the disturbance sequence w t = ( w k ) k = t − L 0 t + L ′ − 1 , and the past output sequence y ini t = ( y k ) k = t − L 0 t − 1 by solving the linear equations (6) Ψ Y p g = col u ini t , u t , w t , y ini t , where g ∈ R M is an intermediate vector. The output prediction is then given by (7) y t = Y f g . Although (6) is generally underdetermined with sufficient data such that M > rank col Ψ , Y p , the output prediction is unique for all solutions to (6) due to the rank condition (5). In this work, optimal controllers are designed to minimize given control objectives J u u t , e.g., energy consumption, subject to input and output constraints u t ∈ U t , y t ∈ Y t at time t . In particular, we consider polytopic output constraints Y t = y t h i t y t ≤ q i t , i = 1 , … , n c . Similar to standard MPC, the scheme is applied in a receding horizon fashion. In detail, replacing the state-space model (1) with predictor (6), (7), the following finite-horizon optimal control problem (OCP) is solved at each time step t : (8a) min u t J u u t (8b) s.t. (6), (7) , u t ∈ U t , h i t y t ≤ q i t , ∀ i = 1 , … , n c . Then, the first element in the optimal control sequence is applied. 2.2 Extensions under noise and uncertainties In practice, however, when there exist noise and uncertainties, the above algorithm cannot be directly applied. This is because the predictor, defined in (6) and (7), is not well-defined when the rank condition (5) no longer holds in the presence of noise. In this work, two sources of uncertainties are considered. (1) Noise in output measurements. This leads to noise in the output part of the signal matrix Y p , Y f , and the past output sequence y ini t with E y ini t = y ̄ ini t , cov y ini t = Σ y . (2) Uncertainties in online disturbance measurements and predictions w t with E w t = w ̄ t , cov w t = Σ w . Three types of modifications to the algorithm have been proposed in the literature. Subspace identification This method aims to recover the rank condition (5) to retain the uniqueness of the predictor, usually via singular value decomposition or QR decomposition [29]. This problem is extensively studied in the subspace identification literature [18]. Although a state-space realization is not required for prediction, the resulting algorithm is equivalent to applying the standard MPC algorithm with state-space models identified by subspace identification [30]. Standard subspace identification algorithms such as N4SID can be directly applied to the signal matrix Z [31]. Indirect data-driven predictive control This method aims to obtain a unique predictor by finding a unique solution g to the underdetermined problem (6). This typically involves solving optimization problems that find the optimal g with respect to some statistical or empirical objectives, i.e., the constraint (6) is replaced by a lower-level optimization problem over g . The control problem then becomes a bi-level OCP, whose usual form is shown below. (9a) min u t J u u t (9b) s.t. y t = Y f g , u t ∈ U t , h i t y t ≤ q i t , ∀ i = 1 , … , n c , (9c) g t = arg min g ‖ Y p g − y ̄ ini t ‖ S 2 + λ ‖ g ‖ 2 2 s.t. Ψ g = col u ini t , u t , w ̄ t , where λ and S are design parameters. The term ‖ Y p g − y ̄ ini t ‖ S 2 penalizes the error in the past output sequence, whereas the term ‖ g ‖ 2 2 is associated with the prediction error [24]. See [24] for a summary on selecting λ and S . Note that the lower-level problem (9c) admits linear closed-form solutions (10) g t = R 1 R 2 R 3 R 4 col u ini t , u t , w ̄ t , y ̄ ini t , where (11) R 1 R 2 R 3 = F − 1 Ψ ⊤ ( Ψ F − 1 Ψ ⊤ ) − 1 , (12) R 4 = F − 1 − F − 1 Ψ ⊤ ( Ψ F − 1 Ψ ⊤ ) − 1 Ψ F − 1 Y p ⊤ S , (13) F = λ I + Y p ⊤ S Y p . So (9c) can be implemented as linear equality constraints. When S = I and λ → 0 , this algorithm is also known as SPC [20]. Direct data-driven predictive control This method allows ill-defined predictors and applies regularization to penalize unreliable predictions. The term ‘direct’ comes from the fact that there is no intermediate input–output mapping derived explicitly. The OCP, in its standard form, becomes: (14a) min u t J u u t + λ g ‖ Π g ‖ p p + λ y ‖ Y p g − y ̄ ini t ‖ 2 2 (14b) s.t. Ψ g = col u ini t , u t , w t , y t = Y f g , (14c) u t ∈ U t , h i t y t ≤ q i t , ∀ i = 1 , … , n c , where the two regularization terms are similar to the objective in the lower-level problem (9c), and λ g , λ y , and Π are design parameters. This type of algorithm is also known as DeePC [21]. However, no systematic approaches have been proposed to tune λ g and λ y . Exhaustive parameter tuning can be extremely time-intensive for systems with large time constants, such as buildings. 2.3 Signal matrix model All three types of algorithms can obtain reasonable performance under noise and uncertainties. However, these predictors only provide nominal predictions and are applied via certainty equivalence. The lack of error quantification makes them problematic to apply in energy systems where safety and reliability are prioritized. Therefore, a stochastic predictor is used to provide high-probability constraint satisfaction, based on the indirect data-driven predictive control paradigm. The prediction error in indirect data-driven predictive control is analyzed in [24] and the results are summarized in Theorem 1. Theorem 1 Signal Matrix Model The L ′ -step-ahead output predictor is given by (15) E y t = y ̄ t , cov y t = Σ t , where (16) y ̄ t = Y f g t − Γ ( Y p g t − y ̄ ini t ) , (17) Σ t = Γ Σ y Γ ⊤ + Γ w Σ w Γ w ⊤ + ‖ g t ‖ 2 2 T , (18) T = σ 2 Γ Γ ⊤ + I , Γ w = ( Y f − Γ Y p ) R 3 , (19) Γ = col C A L 0 , … , C A L − 1 col C , … , C A L 0 − 1 † , is the autonomous transformation matrix from y ini t to y t . Theorem 1 comes directly from the proof of Theorem 1 in [24] by considering augmented inputs u t ⊤ w t ⊤ ⊤ . The predictor (15) is named the signal matrix model. Since the model parameters ( A , C ) are unknown, Γ is not known exactly. In common with [24], it is estimated from Z as (20) Γ ˆ = Y f R 4 in what follows. 2.4 Stochastic indirect data-driven predictive control Theorem 1 quantifies the stochastic prediction error in indirect data-driven predictors. Therefore, indirect data-driven predictive control can be extended to provide stochastic control, using similar techniques to those in stochastic MPC. This leads to the following stochastic control problem. (21a) min u t J u u t (21b) s.t. y t ∼ F u ini t , u t , w ̄ t , y ̄ ini t ; Z , (21c) u t ∈ U t , P h i t y t ≤ q i t ≥ p , ∀ i = 1 , … , n c , where F ( ⋅ ) is the stochastic data-driven predictor, whose mean and covariance are given in Theorem 1. Due to the potentially unbounded noise, the output constraints cannot be satisfied robustly, but only with a high probability p as chance constraints. Unfortunately, the chance constraints (21c) are non-convex. The following proposition provides convex surrogates that guarantee the satisfaction of (21c). Proposition 1 Constraints (21c) are guaranteed by the second-order cone constraints (22) h i t y ̄ t ≤ q i t − μ c 1 + c 2 ‖ g t ‖ 2 , ∀ i = 1 , … , n c , where (23) c 1 = h i t Γ Σ y Γ ⊤ + Γ w Σ w Γ w ⊤ h i t ⊤ , (24) c 2 = h i t T h i t ⊤ , μ = 1 1 − p − 1 . Proof See Appendix.□ Then, we are ready to present the indirect data-driven stochastic predictive control scheme with the signal matrix model. The nominal prediction is given by (16) using the intermediate vector g t given in (10) and the chance constraints are guaranteed by (22). The procedure is summarized in Algorithm 1. Compared with the SMM-PC algorithm proposed in [22,23], Algorithm 1 guarantees chance constraint satisfaction by replacing the nominal constraints with the tightened constraints (22) based on prediction error quantification. It also considers disturbances w t to the system with uncertainties in online disturbance measurement and prediction. The following remarks discuss some modifications to the algorithm. Remark 1 If the distributions of v t , y ini t , and w t are assumed to be Gaussian, the stochastic predictor F ( ⋅ ) is also Gaussian. Constraints (22) can be relaxed by choosing μ = F N − 1 ( p ) , where F N − 1 ( ⋅ ) is the inverse of the cumulative distribution function of a Gaussian distribution. Remark 2 If tracking control is desired, the control objective can be augmented to J ctr u t , y t = J u u t + J y y t , where J y y t = E ‖ y t − r t ‖ Q 2 is the expected output tracking cost and r t is the reference trajectory. The expected output cost is calculated as (26) E ‖ y t − r t ‖ Q 2 = ‖ y ̄ t − r t ‖ Q 2 + E e t ⊤ Q e t = ‖ y ̄ t − r t ‖ Q 2 + tr Q Σ t = ‖ y ̄ t − r t ‖ Q 2 + tr Q T ‖ g t ‖ 2 2 + const , where e t is the prediction error. It includes an additional ‖ g t ‖ 2 2 -penalty term on top of the nominal output cost. Remark 3 The algorithm is rigorously applicable only to linear systems. However, it has been demonstrated numerically [32] and experimentally [33] that such data-driven predictive control algorithms can be effectively applied to nonlinear systems as well. Nonlinearities can be considered as additional output errors in the signal matrix Z . To estimate the magnitude of the combined output error of both the output noise and the nonlinearities, linear system identification is conducted using the n4sid command in Matlab, and the noise level σ 2 is set to the mean squared error of the prediction with the linear model. 3 Case studies A series of numerical and experimental case studies have been carried out to evaluate the performance and transferability of the stochastic SMM-PC algorithm. The studies, summarized in Fig. 1, consider transferability across heterogeneous controlled systems, transferability from simulation to experiment, and the impacts of certain control tasks. The rest of the section elaborates on each case study. 3.1 Controlled systems and tasks Three controlled systems were investigated: a space heating system, a DHW heating system, and a stationary Lithium-ion electric battery, representing typical demand-side resources. All the system configurations and data presented in the rest of the paper are based on the NEST building located at Empa in Switzerland [35], shown in Fig. 2. Typical control tasks include constrained resource planning and trajectory tracking. In the building sector, constrained resource planning is prevalent and aims to minimize total energy consumption while ensuring constraint satisfaction. Reference tracking tasks can also be formulated for the stationary electric battery, as it is considered to be a promising candidate for ancillary service provision through tracking reference signals set by system operators [36]. 3.1.1 Space heating The system considered in this study is a three-room apartment, shown in Fig. 3, hereafter referred to as the UMAR unit. Each room was treated as one thermal zone and heating power was dissipated into the zones through constant volume radiant ceiling panels. The continuous power setpoint, determined by the controller, was realized by regulating the valve opening, which was converted into discrete opening and closing sequences using power-width modulation logic. Additionally, the control of space heating was subject to constraints imposed by occupants’ perception of comfort. Although other indoor conditions also influence occupants’ comfort, temperature sensors are the most commonly available for assessment, so thermal comfort bounds were expressed as temperature limits in this study. As the unit is residential, the thermal comfort bounds were predefined, considering the unit to be unoccupied during the day and occupied during the night. The definition led to relaxed temperature constraints during unoccupied hours. Specifically, the constraints were set to be between 20 ° C and 26 ° C from 08:00 to 16:59 and between 22 ° C and 24 ° C from 17:00 to 07:59 of the second day. Various approaches have been proposed in the literature to compare control algorithms for space heating, ranging from a simulation-only approach using a hypothetical physics-based model [37] to an experiment-only approach with a placebo comparison [10]. The latter requires two identical physical systems running different control algorithms in identical conditions, which is rarely possible in reality. Other studies employ a degree-day metric [7], in which average boundary condition (e.g., ambient temperature) is considered neglecting other factors such as heat gains. In this work, we first benchmarked control algorithms on a high-fidelity white-box model of the physical system shown in Fig. 3 [38]. The model was based on detailed knowledge of the system layout and the heat storage and transfer characteristics of the construction materials. Additionally, the model was calibrated with three-year field measurements at a 1-min temporal resolution, capturing both the dynamics of the physical system and the heat gains due to occupants. Due to the high model fidelity, a high level of confidence in the expected control performance can be ensured. The transparency and reproducibility of the results are ensured by providing the model in an open repository [39]. An experimental study was then conducted to evaluate constraint satisfaction with Algorithm 1 using the signal matrix model. 3.1.2 Domestic hot water heating Energy consumption of DHW is taking an increasing share of the total energy consumption, especially for newly-constructed and renovated buildings with better-insulated envelopes [40]. DHW is often equipped with a water buffer tank as shown in Fig. 4, for hydraulic decoupling and reducing the load diversity factor. Energy scheduling needs to guarantee sufficient hot water storage within the tank and a minimum temperature constraint of 45 °C was considered. Additional periodic temperature boosting to the level of 60 °C is necessary to avoid Legionella contamination [41]. In this work, temperature boosting once per week was considered by introducing a step change in the lower temperature limit, the time series of which can be found in Section 5. The water tank has three temperature sensors vertically distributed along the tank wall, and the measurements differ due to stratification. In the experiment, the average measurement was considered. Lastly, due to high uncertainties associated with individual occupants’ water draw activities, a persistence forecast of water draw was implemented using the most recent weekly water draw patterns. 3.1.3 Stationary electric battery Stationary electric batteries (see Fig. 5) are increasingly popular in the residential sector due to the large mismatch between rooftop solar production and the residential load pattern. Such electricity storage can be used for arbitrage in the electricity market through constrained energy scheduling and for stabilizing power system frequency through reference tracking. Since no standard evaluation metric and use case can be found in the literature, two simple artificial case studies were considered. In the first case study, the amplitudes of battery charging and discharging power were minimized while guaranteeing that the state-of-charge (SOC) was maintained within the predefined dynamic limits. Since the limits varied over time, knowledge of the future system response was necessary. In the second case study, the battery’s charging and discharging powers were controlled such that its SOC followed a reference signal. Although classical PID control schemes also excel at reference tracking and the future system response is not crucial to consider, this case study was carried out to cover all possible applications. Detailed time-series views of the dynamic limits and reference signal are provided in Section 5. 3.2 Simulation and experimental configurations Both simulation and experimental studies were conducted to evaluate the proposed algorithm. The simulation study was mainly used to benchmark multiple data-driven control algorithms under the same boundary conditions and the experimental study validated the performance and the transferability in real configurations. 3.2.1 Simulation The performance of multiple data-driven control algorithms was benchmarked in a space heating example using the high-fidelity testbed nestli [38]. Its core uses an EnergyPlus model of the UMAR unit in the NEST building, the layout of which is shown in Fig. 3. To actively override variables during the simulation, the EnergyPlus model was wrapped into a functional mock-up unit (FMU) and integrated into a Simulink simulation model. This provides a digital twin for accurate benchmarking of different control algorithms. Matlab & Simulink simulations were conducted to implement space heating control of the three main rooms (Rooms 272, 273, and 274 in Fig. 3) in UMAR using the Matlab version of [38]. The three rooms were separately controlled. The control sample time was 15 min. For each room, the controller was implemented as follows. Input: The heating power [kW] was considered as the input u t and was constrained to be positive and upper-bounded by the maximum heating power. The maximum heating power depends on the difference between the supply and the return temperatures [ ° C ]. Since the heating system was not modeled in this case study, constant temperature differences were considered throughout the control horizon. The input command was implemented by pulse-width modulation of binary valve position with a 1-min resolution. Output: The room temperature [ ° C ] was considered as the output y t . Output noise with a variance of 0.01 was added to all measurements. Disturbance: The ambient temperature [ ° C ] and the global horizontal irradiance [W/m 2 ] were considered as the disturbances w t . The variances of the ambient temperature and the irradiance predictions were assumed to be 0.04 and 25 respectively. Objective: The control objective was to minimize the total energy consumption within the control horizon, i.e., J u u t = ‖ u t ‖ 1 . The following data-driven algorithms were compared in simulation. SMM-PC Algorithm 1 was applied using the minimum mean-squared error predictor described in [24] with S = Γ ̄ ⊤ Γ ̄ , λ = n y L σ 2 + tr S σ 2 , where Γ ̄ is the last n y L columns of Y f col Ψ , Y p † . This design shows a good prediction accuracy in [24]. N4SID A state-space model of order n x = L 0 was identified by subspace identification in the innovation form: (27) x ˆ t + 1 = A ˆ x ˆ t + B ˆ u t + E ˆ w t + L ˆ e t , y t = C ˆ x ˆ t + D ˆ u t + e t using the Matlab command n4sid, where A ˆ , B ˆ , C ˆ , D ˆ , E ˆ , and L ˆ are the estimated model parameters, x ˆ t is the state estimate, and e t quantifies the model error whose variance was estimated by n4sid. The stochastic MPC with chance constraints described in [42] was implemented by considering both the stochastic model error e t and the disturbance uncertainty in w t . BiLevel The robust bi-level data-driven control algorithm presented in [11] was implemented. The algorithm augments the standard indirect data-driven predictive control (9c) with robustness to bounded disturbance uncertainties and an affine disturbance feedback term [43]. Since stochastic disturbance uncertainties were considered in this work, a high-probability disturbance set described with w t ∈ w t w t − w ̄ t ⊤ Σ w − 1 w t − w ̄ t ≤ μ was used. Note that the online adaptation in [11] was not implemented for a fair comparison against other algorithms. DeePC The direct data-driven predictive control algorithm described in [32] (specifically its Eq. (16)) was implemented by choosing p = 2 , Π = I − col Ψ , Y p † col Ψ , Y p , and a sufficiently large λ y value. Nominal output constraints were enforced since this approach cannot quantify the prediction error due to its implicit predictor structure. The three competing algorithms (N4SID, BiLevel, and DeePC) were selected to represent the state-of-the-art practices for the three types of data-driven predictive control algorithms described in Section 2.2, respectively. The following parameters were used in the controllers: L 0 = 10 (2.5 h), L ′ = 15 (3.75 h), and p = 0 . 7 . All the OCPs were solved by Gurobi. In addition, a hysteresis controller was considered as the baseline. 3.2.2 Experiment The experimental work concerns cases with space heating, DHW, and a stationary Lithium-ion electric battery. The information exchange schematic is depicted in Fig. 6, which includes querying historical measurements, weather forecasts, and forwarding setpoints to actuators. Numerical weather forecasts for the next 72 h were provided by MeteoSwiss [44] twice a day at an hourly resolution and measurements at a 1-min resolution were collected using programmable logic controllers (PLCs) equipped for each controlled system and stored in the NEST database. This database was accessed via REST API [45] over HTTPS and an open platform communications (OPC) server was used to forward real-time control decisions to the actuators, such as the valves and the DC/AC power inverter. 4 Simulation results This section presents the simulation results from the case study described in Section 3.2. Historical weather data from November 7 to December 7 of 2020 were used to run the simulations. The learning data used to construct the signal matrix Z were collected from November 7 to November 30 of 2020 by running the default hysteresis controller. This corresponds to 2 ′ 305 data points. The data-driven controllers were applied from December 1 to December 7 of 2020, after an initialization phase of 2.5 h corresponding to the length of L 0 . Monte Carlo simulations of 20 runs were conducted for each algorithm with different measurement noise and disturbance uncertainties realizations. All the considered predictive control algorithms performed significantly better than the baseline hysteresis control, with a 20%–27% reduction in energy consumption and a 30%–93% reduction in constraint violation. So in what follows, we focus on benchmarking different data-driven predictive control algorithms. Results of energy consumption and temperature constraint violation for the three controlled rooms are shown in Fig. 7. It can be seen that the SMM-PC algorithm outperformed the other algorithms in terms of both energy consumption and constraint satisfaction for all three rooms. Specifically, compared to N4SID, BiLevel, and DeePC, SMM-PC reduced the constraint violation by 59%, 77%, and 90% with an average energy saving of 8%, 6%, and 4%, respectively. A comparison of input–output trajectories in one representative simulation is shown in Fig. 8. One can observe that SMM-PC was more conservative in regulating the room temperature to avoid constraint violation. It is worth mentioning that the control decisions of SMM-PC were also smoother than other algorithms which implied reduced hardware wear in practice. This empirical observation can be further explored in future studies. The SMM-PC algorithm is analyzed more closely in Fig. 9, where the one-step-ahead prediction and the tightened bounds of SMM-PC are also plotted for Room 272 as an example. The tightened bounds for N4SID, which were calculated offline based on an estimate of the model error, are also shown for comparison. The predicted room temperature was very close to the true room temperature, and the tightened bounds provided in Proposition 1 were more conservative than N4SID leading to fewer constraint violations. The same plot for BiLevel is shown in Fig. 10. Although the prediction accuracy was also acceptable, it underestimated the prediction error, leading to more constraint violations. This is expected since BiLevel is only robust to errors in disturbance prediction but not to measurement errors. In the results presented above, we selected λ g = 1 0 4 for DeePC, which was the best-performing one in our tests with λ g = 1 0 i , i = 2 , 3 , 4 , 5 , 6 . For this λ g choice, the behaviors of BiLevel and DeePC were similar as shown in Fig. 8, except that there was no constraint tightening for DeePC. This validates the statement in [32] that direct and indirect methods are equivalent for sufficiently large λ g with nominal predictions. However, the DeePC algorithm may fail for small λ g values. Fig. 11 illustrates one scenario where DeePC was incapable of providing reasonable temperature control for Room 273 with λ g = 1 0 2 . Finally, to further evaluate the reliability of the algorithms, two scenarios with deteriorated uncertainties were considered: (1) the temperature measurements are less accurate with a 10 times larger variance of the output noise, and (2) the disturbance prediction is less accurate with 10 times larger variances for both the ambient temperature and the irradiance. The Monte Carlo simulations were repeated for these two scenarios and the results are shown in Table 1. It can be observed that SMM-PC remained the best in terms of both energy consumption and constraint violation in both scenarios. In addition, the performance of SMM-PC in these two scenarios was very consistent compared to the nominal case despite increased uncertainties, whereas an increase in energy consumption in Room 273 was observed for the other algorithms. The performance of the BiLevel algorithm deteriorated particularly in Scenario 1 as the algorithm cannot handle large output noise. All of these simulation results indicate that the SMM-PC algorithm is more effective than the other algorithms in terms of energy consumption, constraint satisfaction, and consistent performance. In practical terms, this suggests that SMM-PC is an efficient and reliable choice for practical deployment, especially in scenarios where measurement errors often vary across different buildings. 5 Experimental results In this section, we first validate controller performance on the physical space heating system on which the high-fidelity model in the previous section has been built. Then the transferability of the algorithm to other controlled systems is assessed. 5.1 Space heating The experiment was carried out between February 7 and February 11 of 2023. During the experiment, the prediction horizon and the confidence level of constraint satisfaction were set to be 15 (3.75 h) and 0.7, respectively. They were the same as the values used in the simulation study. The experimental results summarized in Fig. 12 include temperature measurements, control decisions, and realized power inputs into each temperature zone. Different from the numerical study in the previous section, the actuation of control decisions is subject to errors in practice, leading to mismatches between control decisions and realized power inputs in Fig. 12. It can be observed that the temperature in each room was maintained within the predefined comfort zone most of the time. The accumulated constraint violations in Rooms 272, 273, and 274 are 0.025 ° C h, 2.159 ° C h, and 1.518 ° C h, respectively. Additionally, in all rooms, preheating decisions can be observed once the step increase of the lower temperature limits was within the horizon of the controller. The results validated the hypothesis that SMM-PC is able to ensure constraint satisfaction within the technical capability of the underlying physical system. 5.2 Domestic hot water heating The experimental results of DHW heating control are summarized in Fig. 13, where both water draw and average tank temperature time series are shown together with predefined temperature limits. It can be observed that average tank temperatures were mostly maintained within the predefined limits. The accumulated constraint violation over one week was observed to be 3.9 ° C h. Since the control task was to minimize energy consumption, the tank temperature was kept close to the lower limit leaving only necessary hot water, which contributed to reducing heat loss through the tank wall. Large constraint violation was observed when the step change of the lower temperature limit occurred due to decontamination. This was due to the large uncertainty level in the water draw activities and the narrow feasible bound during decontamination, which result in the infeasibility of the tightened constraints. In other words, the data-driven algorithm was not able to guarantee high-probability constraint satisfaction with the available data. In this case, it is recommended to relax the output constraints and/or to include more data on the water draw activities to provide data-driven load forecasts. 5.3 Stationary electric battery The experimental results of the electric battery control are shown in Fig. 14 for both the resource planning task and the reference tracking task. The resource planning results show that the SOC of the battery was maintained within the limits verifying the constraint satisfaction hypothesis. The accumulated constraint violation was 15.95% h. Since the SOC limits were artificially designed, the accumulated constraint satisfaction value was not a crucial performance indicator. In this experiment, a high confidence level of 0.95 was used, so the actual SOC profile appeared to be conservative and the trajectory stayed in the middle of the predefined zone to actively avoid constraint violation. The results of the reference tracking experiment show remarkable precision; in fact, the root mean square error between the reference signal and the actual SOC is only 0.79%. To put it in context, the measurement quantization error is 0.5%. Both experiments confirm the applicability of SMM-PC to typical control tasks for electric batteries. 5.4 Discussion The experimental results revealed that the SMM-PC algorithm performed well in terms of constraint satisfaction and its performance can be transferred to different types of systems with minimal tuning effort. Therefore, the SMM-PC algorithm has the potential to enable large-scale deployment of DSM across heterogeneous systems timely. The optimal selection of historical measurements as the input-disturbance-output trajectory data is a nuanced task and beyond the scope of this study. Nonetheless, a potential solution involves combining long datasets including relevant periods with preconditioning of data matrices, as suggested in [22]. Expert knowledge can assist in identifying periods with sufficient system excitation. In the example of room heating, including periods with variable thermal power input and temperature fluctuations is crucial. Lastly, even though the methodology is only rigorously proven for linear systems, the numerical and experimental studies in this work show that it can be effectively applied to nonlinear systems by considering nonlinearity as an additional source of error, with better performance than conventional algorithms based on linear system identification. 6 Conclusion Scalable modeling and control frameworks can facilitate demand side management, a critical tool for the reliable and efficient operation of future energy systems. To address current limitations, this work proposes a novel data-driven predictive control algorithm using the signal matrix model. By using a stochastic control framework, this algorithm is designed to be reliable against noise and disturbances. The performance of the methodology is comprehensively evaluated in high-fidelity simulations by comparing it against other data-driven predictive control approaches, and its transferability is validated in multiple experimental studies. Two main conclusions can be drawn from the quantitative results. Firstly, compared to the state-of-the-art data-driven predictive control algorithms, the proposed algorithm can improve occupants’ thermal comfort and energy saving by up to 90% and 8%, respectively. Secondly, the algorithm effectively ensures constraint satisfaction, and its performance can be transferred to other systems with minimal tuning effort. Therefore, the proposed algorithm can facilitate large-scale deployment of demand side management to support energy system operation. To conclude, several limitations must be noted. First, while data-driven approaches provide scalability, the interpretability of the decisions still needs to be assessed. Poor interpretability could potentially compromise the security of a system comprising many automated and distributed devices, which are aggregated to support a secure grid operation in the first place. Second, while the transferability across different controlled systems was evaluated, it remains to be assessed for the same type of controlled systems with different characteristics. For example, the proposed algorithm needs to be tested on a large group of heterogeneous buildings with different heating input systems. coredata.dc:description: Demand side management is perceived as a tool to support a secure and reliable energy system operation amid growing integration of renewable energy resources. However, the lack of scalable modeling and control procedures hinders the practical implementation. To address this challenge, this paper proposes a novel signal matrix model predictive control algorithm. Compared to existing data-driven methods, this approach explicitly provides stochastic predictions considering both disturbance and measurement errors with few tuning parameters, ensuring reliability by high-probability constraint satisfaction. The performance is extensively compared with three state-of-the-art algorithms in a space heating case study using a high-fidelity simulator. The results are further validated with physical experiments using the same system that the simulator is based on. To assess transferability, the algorithm is further implemented on diverse controlled systems, including a domestic hot water heating system and a stationary electric battery. The simulation results show that, compared to existing data-driven methods, the proposed approach improves constraint satisfaction and energy savings by up to 90 % and 8 %, respectively. The experimental results further confirm that the algorithm is applicable to multiple tasks of demand side management, with reasonable control performance observed in all case studies.
